ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned lots. The course promises on its title. Very memorable course.
Gained a new perspective on gender and racial changes within the United States over the last century
Gender, justice, power, institutions.
Really deepened my understanding of the context and debates around a lot of issues that come up often in the news.
I honestly don't feel as though I learned very much.
I loved how this course really did a wonderful job introducing and demonstrated the interconnectivity of justice, gender and power.

I gained a surface level covering of the syllabus's main topics. Otherwise I do not feel that I gained anything meaningful at all from this class. The class felt like we were just hearing opinions about issues, without close consideration towards arguments, and then just moving swiftly on. Given the expected authority of a professor or TF, these opinions were being taught to us like facts. This meant that it either confirmed our initial beliefs, or conflicted and so were ignored. There was no exploration or challenging of any ideas. Professor Fischel made unsupported claims, seemingly based on his own opinions/preferences, which felt a disservice given that this was my first time exploring this field, and I had expected an objective and rounded semester. Some of the TF's presentations were even more dramatic examples of this, where it felt like they had a certain view they wanted to defend and I left the lecture not feeling any more educated on the topic but instead just more aware of that person's perspective.
This was an excellent course that allowed room for open engagement and learning.
I developed knowledge about social issues, and their philosophical and historical roots.
I learned more about gender, justice, and power, and how they interact in modern-day institutions.
Ways to think about interdisciplinary content regarding the role of gender in society.
I learned about so many different movements and theories behind gender, justice, power, and institutions. I appreciated learning about the laws that have shaped these movements as well.
it was mostly a survey course of a lot of hot button issues (bathrooms, abortion, consent, etc)

Great course overviewing the importance, history, and happenings in topics regarding gender, Justice, power, and institutions. The topics were all highly engaging and intersected the four pillars of the class nicely. Great speakers were brought in and interesting materials were used.
Learnt lots about current political topics. Learnt to question things that i had previously just accepted.
Interrelations of gender, justice, power, and institutions through current topics such as abortion, heterosexual culture, neoliberalism, prison and a philosophical lens
A fantastic overview of how gender and sexuality influence/ are influenced by justice and power in our society.

I learn about deeper and progressive ideas, got involved in conversations ingrained in US societies. The course materials really interested me and I enjoyed reading them a lot. It is always nice to have these sort of classes, while challenging you intellectually also works a mental health recovery.
Broad theories of justice, gender, power, ethics, race and their intersectionality. Very applicable to current events.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: STRENGTHS: Never had to worry too much about this class but learned a lot. Lectures and readings are very informative and not that intimidating if you have no background in philosophy or gender studies. Joe and the TFs are great. WEAKNESSES: some topics are uncomfortable to talk about and some lectures are intense - you should read the syllabus carefully (pretty much every trigger warning imaginable, including some gory/graphic stuff discussed in a lecture about the limits of consent)
More ability for students to find readings they connect with

In lecture, Professor Fischer usually spends about half of the time reviewing what he went over the lecture prior. I don't think this is particularly helpful nor engaging. I wish he would just actually lecture during the whole lecture.

Strengths
The workload was relaxed and the readings were very reasonable but I still felt like I got so much out of the course, readings and sections!
Such a great class honestly

I don't think there's a need to recap the previous lecture every lecture, as it takes up more than half the time, and we often ran out of time to discuss the actually relevant topics. I feel like slides could be enhanced by using the space the briefly point toward key points of the lecture, rather than background information, as sometimes Joe's lectures were a bit confusing and seemed scattered. I also feel like the justice unit could be enhanced as it felt out of context with the rest of course at times.
I wish that the lectures were recorded and posted on canvas.

Students having to argue opposing views in section and more closely engage with arguments and course content. I do not feel that views were openly discussed at all, which I had expected to be central to the class.
The professor was truly amazing.
This is a really fantastic course. I found the readings and assignments to be very engaging.

One of the strengths of this course is its lectures and unique content.

This course has no weaknesses.
No weakness!

Strengths: Professor Fischel does a great job of contextualizing the information. The quizzes meant I was more motivated to attend class and do the readings. Some of the readings / podcasts / videos were super engaging. Fischel also makes an effort to bring in guest speakers and share talks and discussions happening on campus, which I appreciated. Professor Fischel talks very quickly but does a lot of review, which I found super helpful. Weaknesses: some of the readings were very dense and made discussion in section difficult.
too broad. but the teaching staff was incredible
sometimes reading was too heavy so i wouldnt do it all

strengths: interesting readings, low stress class, engaging lectures; weaknesses: class time often felt too short, sometimes low workload/stress of the class made so that many people did not do the readings/show up to lecture

Strengths: very manageable workload, engaging coursework, section discussions were insightful, professor is very engaging.
Weaknesses: none
Strengths: straightforward and fun assignments that encourage engagement with course material. Extremely interesting professor with fun lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Very interesting material and never stressful. Just pay attention in lecture (and attend) and you'll get an A. Tons of extra credit opportunities and ways to engage with the class outside of lecture as well.
I would recommend this course. The information was so interesting and always very intellectually stimulating which I enjoyed thoroughly.
Yes, very interesting course
YES! GREAT CLASS
Definitely. It was pretty easy and very interesting!
YES such a great class

Honestly, no. The course seemed interesting from the title, and I'm usually interested in these topics, but the course was unengaging. I felt almost no motivation to do the readings. I took this course mainly for an SS credit, but even then, I feel like I could have taken a more engaging course. The course had a lot of breadth but not a lot of depth. The course also seemed to perfectly align with a book the professor was writing at the same time, which isn't necessarily bad, but it's usually a red flag and kind of showed at times... I would only recommend if you had to or if you just really wanted a gut because this is a gutty gut.
Yes I think its a great course for anyone wanting to learn more about a variety of different topics that are ever important in this day and age.
Yes if you need a gut
Yes, this was an amazing course.
Yes! This is a wonderful class.
Yes! This class gives a great overview of how the concepts of GJPI interact with one another. The different assignments also encourage non-traditional forms of learning that are very refreshing.
Absolutely, Professor Fischel is a wonderful lecturer and has so much knowledge to offer.
Yes! You learn a lot and there is such a breadth of material covered that it appeals to many people of different interests.

Yes! I am so grateful I took this course as a PLSC major and student interested in WGSS. Its accessible and welcoming. I would say that section can be difficult to follow if you dont attend lectures or do the readings. Its really one of those get-out-what-you-put-in classes.

yes! i took this class to get a broader understanding of social issues I was seeing in the news. the space is super inclusive, and if you have dumb questions you don't want to sound ignorant asking, the teaching staff is really good about being inclusive and talking about uncomfortable topics!
Very interesting class for any students who want to learn more about gender and sexuality in the modern world.
yes! a great fifth class -- engaging, thought-provoking, and stimulating but not stressful
Yes! One of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale.
Yessssss absolutely!
Yes! Great to understand the history behind many current, relevant political issues and their movements.
